info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued August 02 at 2:54PM PDT by NWS Medford
info.description: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of southeastern Jackson and southwestern Klamath Counties through 315 PM PDT... At 251 PM PDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7 miles north of Topsy Campground, or 14 miles west of Klamath Falls, moving east at 20 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 30 mph and half inch hail. SOURCE...Radar indicated. IMPACT...Heavy rainfall will reduce visibilities, result in slick roads, and cause localized ponding of water. Dangerous cloud to ground lightning is also expected. Locations impacted include... Hagelstein County Park, Spring Island Boat Launch, Eagle Ridge Klamath County Park, Howard Bay Park, Keno, Klamath River Campground and Topsy Campground. This includes the following highways... US 97 in Oregon between mile markers 260 and 267. Lake of the Woods Highway 140 in Oregon between mile markers 49 and 65. Highway 66 in Oregon between mile markers 28 and 54. MAX HAIL SIZE...0.50 IN MAX WIND GUST...30 MPH
info.instruction: If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building. Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways. Frequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm. Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe shelter inside a building or vehicle. This storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio stations and available television stations for additional information and possible warnings from the National Weather Service. If on or near Upper Klamath Lake, get out of the water and move indoors or inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 10 miles from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now! Do not be caught on the water in a thunderstorm. Persons in campgrounds should consider seeking sturdy shelter until this storm passes.
